description:
Toxorhynchites rutilus septentrionalis is a species of mosquito belonging to the genus Toxorhynchites, also known as the "elephant mosquito" or "toxorhynchite mosquito." This species is found in the northern regions of North America, including Canada and the northeastern United States.

Toxorhynchites rutilus septentrionalis is a relatively large mosquito, with a body length of around 10-15 millimeters. They have a distinctive appearance, with a long, slender proboscis (mouthpart) and a rounded, humpbacked thorax. The body coloration is typically dark brown or black, with white or silvery markings on the abdomen and legs.

Unlike many other mosquito species, Toxorhynchites rutilus septentrionalis are not blood-feeders. Instead, the adults feed on nectar and other plant-based liquids. The larvae, however, are predatory and feed on the larvae of other mosquito species, making them important natural control agents for mosquito populations.

The life cycle of Toxorhynchites rutilus septentrionalis involves the female laying her eggs in water-filled containers, such as tree holes, artificial containers, or other natural or man-made aquatic habitats. The larvae hatch and go through several developmental stages before emerging as adults.

This species is considered beneficial to the ecosystem, as the larvae help to regulate the populations of other, potentially more harmful mosquito species. Additionally, Toxorhynchites rutilus septentrionalis are not known to transmit any diseases to humans or other animals.
